channel.title: Daily on Shared Prayers
channel.description: Recent content in Daily on Shared Prayers

item.title: Daily Devotions -- In the Morning
item.description: according to the Book of Common Prayer (p. 137) From Psalm 51 Open my lips, O Lord, * and my mouth shall proclaim your praise. Create in me a clean heart, O God, * and renew a right spirit within me. Cast me not away from your presence * and take not your holy Spirit from me. Give me the joy of your saving help again * and sustain me with your bountiful Spirit.

item.title: Daily Devotions -- At Noon
item.description: according to the Book of Common Prayer (p. 138) From Psalm 113 Give praise, you servants of the Lord; * praise the Name of the Lord. Let the Name of the Lord be blessed, * from this time forth for evermore. From the rising of the sun to its going down * let the Name of the Lord be praised. The Lord is high above all nations, *

item.title: Daily Devotions -- In the Early Evening
item.description: according to the Book of Common Prayer (p. 139) This devotion may be used before or after the evening meal. O gracious light, pure brightness of the everliving Father in heaven, O Jesus Christ, holy and blessed! Now as we come to the setting of the sun, and our eyes behold the vesper light, we sing your praises, O God: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. You are worthy at all times to be praised by happy voices,

item.title: Daily Devotions -- At the Close of Day
item.description: according to the Book of Common Prayer (p. 140) Psalm 134 Behold now, bless the Lord, all you servants of the Lord, * you that stand by night in the house of the Lord. Lift up your hands in the holy place and bless the Lord; * the Lord who made heaven and earth bless you out of Zion. A Reading Lord, you are in the midst of us and we are called by your Name: Do not forsake us, O Lord our God.

item.title: Evening Prayer for Sundays in the Season after Pentecost, Rite Two
item.description: This liturgy leaves spaces for the Psalm and up to three lessons. A reader might hold these passages ready to share at the appropriate places in the liturgy. On Saturday nights of Sundays, if this service is taking the place of a Eucharist, one might wish to use lessons from the Eucharistic Lectionary, which can be conveniently found at lectionarypage.net. Lessons for the daily office can be found in the Book of Common Prayer on pp.

item.title: Morning Prayer for Sundays in Lent, Rite Two
item.description: This liturgy leaves spaces for the Psalm and up to three lessons. A reader might hold these passages ready to share at the appropriate places in the liturgy. Lessons for the daily office can be found in the Book of Common Prayer on pp. 936ff. If you don’t have a Bible handy, specific passages can be looked up on [http://bible.oremus.org/](oremus Bible Browser). On Sundays one might wish to use lessons from the Eucharistic Lectionary instead, which can be conveniently found at https://lectionarypage.

item.title: Daily Morning Prayer, Rite Two - Full Static Template
item.description: The Officiant begins the service with one or more of these sentences of Scripture, or with the versicle “Lord, open our lips” on page 80. Advent Watch, for you do not know when the master of the house will come, in the evening, or at midnight, or at cockcrow, or in the morning, lest he come suddenly and find you asleep. (Mark 13:35, 36) In the wilderness prepare the way of the Lord, make straight in the desert a highway for our God.

item.title: Daily Morning Prayer, Rite Two -- Automated Template
item.description: Officiant: The glory of the Lord shall be revealed, and all flesh shall see it together. (Isaiah 40:5) Confession of Sin Officiant: Let us confess our sins against God and our neighbor. The people kneel or stand as able. Silence may be kept. Officiant and People: Most merciful God, we confess that we have sinned against you in thought, word, and deed, by what we have done,

item.title: An Order for Compline
item.description: The Officiant begins The Lord Almighty grant us a peaceful night and a perfect end. People Amen. Officiant Our help is in the Name of the Lord; People The maker of heaven and earth. The Officiant may then say Let us confess our sins to God. Officiant and People Almighty God, our heavenly Father: We have sinned against you,

item.title: An Order of Service for Noonday
item.description: Officiant O God, make speed to save us. People O Lord, make haste to help us. Officiant and People Glory to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit: * as it was in the beginning, is now, and will be for ever. Amen. Except in Lent, add Alleluia. A suitable hymn may be sung. One or more of the following Psalms is sung or said.

item.title: An Order of Service for Noonday (None)
item.description: Officiant O God, make speed to save us. People O Lord, make haste to help us. Officiant and People Glory to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit: * as it was in the beginning, is now, and will be for ever. Amen. Except in Lent, add Alleluia. Psalm 126 In convertendo 1 When the LORD restored the fortunes of Zion, *

item.title: An Order of Service for Noonday (Sext)
item.description: Officiant O God, make speed to save us. People O Lord, make haste to help us. Officiant and People Glory to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit: * as it was in the beginning, is now, and will be for ever. Amen. Except in Lent, add Alleluia. A suitable hymn may be sung. Psalm 121 Levavi oculos 1 I lift up my eyes to the hills; *

item.title: An Order of Service for Noonday (Terce)
item.description: Officiant O God, make speed to save us. People O Lord, make haste to help us. Officiant and People Glory to the Father, and to the Son, and to the Holy Spirit: * as it was in the beginning, is now, and will be for ever. Amen. Except in Lent, add Alleluia. A suitable hymn may be sung. Psalm 119 Lucerna pedibus meis
